column2: On the 24th of June 1839 Von Moltke took control of the Ottoman artillery at the Battle of Nezib. Prior to the battle he had pleaded with Hafiz Pasha to take a more fortified position, initially Hafiz was receptive this advice but his other advisors swayed him into holding his ground. The Ottoman force was beaten by the Egyptian artillery and Moltke made his way back to Istanbul. By the time he returned to the capital his patron Sultan Mahmud II had passed away.

Les Trois Mousquetaires, a novel set in 17th century France, has been written in by Alexandre Dumas and Auguste Maguet. Initially published serially in one of the $YEAR$ publications of Le Siècle, The Three Musketeers tells the story of the early adventures of the young Gascon gentleman, D'Artagnan and his three friends from the regiment of the King's Musketeers - Athos, Porthos and Aramis. Under the watchful eye of their patron M. de Treville, the four defend the honour of the regiment against the guards of Cardinal Richelieu, and the honour of the queen against the machinations of the Cardinal himself as the power struggles of seventeenth century France are vividly played out in the background.

A Tale of Two Cities, initially published serially by Charles Dickens in his periodical All the Year Round, has recently been finished, the 31st installment ending the 45 chapter novel. This book, one of only two of works of historical fiction by Dickens, depicts the plight of the French peasantry demoralised by the French aristocracy in the years leading up to the revolution, the corresponding brutality demonstrated by the revolutionaries toward the former aristocrats in the early years of the revolution, and many unflattering social parallels with life in London during the same period.

Initially appearing in the Russian periodical Russkiy Vestnik, War and Peace has finally been published in $YEAR$, 2 years after its final serialized debut. Initially titled "1805" by the author Leo Tolstoy, War and Peace chronicles the history of the French Invasion of Russia and the impact of the Napoleonic Era as seen through the accounts of five aristocratic families. The author has said that War and Peace "is not a novel, even less is it a poem, and still less a historical chronicle". Large sections, especially the later chapters, are a philosophical discussion rather than narrative. The first publications sold out overnight, readers of the serialized edition coming in droves to purchase it.
This story stands as a testament to $COUNTRY_ADJ$ culture.

Le Tour du Monde en Quatre-vingts Jours, the 11th installment of the Extraordinary Voyages series, has been published in $YEAR$ by Jules Verne. In the story, The main character, Phileas Fogg of London and his newly employed French valet Passepartout attempt to circumnavigate the world in 80 days on a 20,000 pound wager set by his friends at the Reform Club. The novel weaves together the three main themes of Time, Technology, and Imperialism over the course of the worldwide trip. Around the World in 80 Days remains one of the crowning achievements of Jules Verne and one of the defining works of the Victorian Era.

El Gaucho Martin Fierro, a 2,316-line long epic poem by writer José Hernández, has been finished. Together with the second installment, La Vuelta de Martin Fierro (The Return of Martin Fierro), the poem tells the story of the eponymous protagonist, an impoverished gaucho, who was drafted to serve at a border fort against the native population. His romanticized life on the pampas tells his adventures ranging from deserting in an attempt to go home only to find everything he loved gone, deliberately provoking an affair of honor by insulting a black woman in a bar killing her male companion on the ensuing knife duel, becoming an outlaw and other many tales. The story is seen by many as one of the most important pieces of Argentine literature and a window into the life of the Gaucho.
Great stories can be found in the strangest places.

In $YEAR$, the Milanese launched an anti-Austrian campaign as early as 1 January. On New Years Day the Milanese started to boycott gambling and tobacco products, which were government monopolies that brought in over 5 million lire a year. The boycott culminated in a bloody street battle on 3 January, when Austrian soldiers, in batches of three, were being insulted and pelted with stones by an angry crowd. The soldiers then gathered together in groups of a dozen and charged the crowd with swords and bayonets, killing five and wounding another 59. Radetzky confined his troops to barracks for five days. The protests were over, but two months later, when news reached Milan of the uprising in Vienna and the fall of Metternich, the Milanese took to the streets again, on 18 March.
Let's teach them a lesson again!
We have no choice but to let them go.

Across Italy, discomfort with foreign domination and with absolute monarchy had led to all Italian states (apart from Lombardy-Venetia) becoming parliamentary monarchies with much of the reform led by Pope Pius IX. Heavy-handed policing in response to an economic boycott of state monopolies in Austrian-held Milan led to the popular expulsion of the Austrian garrison in the city for five days in $YEAR$. Shortly after, the news of revolt in Vienna spreading to Venice lead the city to revolt against the Austrian rule, with the beginnings of Venetian independence.
We have no choice but to let them go.
